title: Definition and Scope of Communication
introduction: Communication is the process of sharing information and ideas between people or groups. It is important in both business and private life. Developing strong communication skills is a top priority for leaders. Express your thoughts in a simple way so that everyone can understand.

content.value: Effective communication offers many benefits:
Listening
It uses understanding of spoken or written information, it also builds how you need to speak.
It allows everyone to express ideas, opinions, feelings, plans, and problems.
Straight Talking
Discuss with friends or colleagues on the topic given, build some mutual trust and solve the problem before the issue is serious.
Talking about the topic to most of the people who you trusted makes clear ideas on solving the issue.
Non Verbal

When we talk we will have more non verbal. But keep much focus on break less communication, body position/seating, facial expression, your posture, eye contact, voice tone, Whatever you speak be confident even if it is non verbal.
Make sure that your thoughts have reached the other person properly.
Research in 2014 showed that marketing professionals rely on more than 90% non-verbal communication while selling a brand/product.
Be Clear
while writing or speaking, be clear on the message
Concise
stick to the point and keep it brief about the topic (don’t deviate from the topic)
Concrete
if the message is concrete from your side, the audience will have a clear picture of what you are telling
Coherent (Logical)
if the communication is logical, all points will connect to the relevant topic
Complete
Make sure the audience has everything they need about the topic given to you
Courteous
Communicate in a friendly, open, and honest manner

items: Ask any of your friends to give honest feedback to help you understand your area for improvement in communication. It can help you identify what to focus on. (If your friends criticize your communication, don’t feel bad.)
Many skills are habits you develop over time. With regular practice, you can become a good communicator.
Attend more communication workshops like online or offline seminars. Attend more classes to practice which includes instruction, role-play, written assignment and open discussion.
Always try to grab the opportunity to develop your skills.
Listening only doesn’t help you; you need to practice and participate

content.value: Listen
Most of us do more talking than listening. Make sure to take the time to really listen to what people are saying by their words, tone and body language.
Come alongside the other person
Please agree with your friend on the discussion and create trust in you. Don’t judge or try to correct. Try to support and let them know you care.
Check your tone and body language
Please check your tone and body language always during the conversation.
Be Real
Be real to the communicator. Don’t be frustrated, be real and honest.

exercises.title: Effective Communication Analysis
exercises.instructions: Read each scenario and identify which of the Six Cs of communication is being violated.

questions.question: A manager sends an email with vague instructions for a project without specifying deadlines or expected outcomes.
questions.answer: Clear - The communication lacks clarity about expectations and timelines.

questions.question: A presenter spends 10 minutes giving background information unrelated to the topic before getting to the main point.
questions.answer: Concise - The communication contains unnecessary information that distracts from the main message.

questions.question: A team leader sends an update that contains several contradictory statements about project priorities.
questions.answer: Coherent - The communication lacks logical flow and contains contradictory information.

exercises.title: Communication Improvement Plan
exercises.instructions: Create a personal communication improvement plan by identifying one weakness in your communication style and three specific actions you can take to improve it.

questions.question: Sample response: Weakness - I tend to interrupt others when they're speaking. Improvement actions: 1) Wait three seconds after someone finishes speaking before responding, 2) Take notes while others are speaking, 3) Ask follow-up questions to show I'm engaged.
questions.answer: This is a reflection exercise. Answers will vary, but should include a specific weakness and concrete improvement actions.
